results.title: Election: behind the polls
results.creator_credit: Film Australia, Matt Scully and Kate Stone
results.brief_description: This documentary takes a look behind the scenes at the organising of an election. The role of the Australian Electoral Commission is examined, including such issues as the dissemination of how to vote information, the setting up of the national tally room and polling stations in suburban and remote areas of Australia, arranging postal voting and voting for those who are not able to get to a polling station, and counting of the votes. The role of the Governor General in dissolving the Parliament and associated duties are also examined.

results.title: Election
results.creator_credit: Paramount Pictures, MTV Films, Bona Fide Productions, Albert Berger, Ron Yerxa, David Gale, Keith Samples and Alexander Payne
results.brief_description: Matthew Broderick plays Jim McAllister, a popular and well respected teacher at George Washington Carver High School. Reese Witherspoon is Tracy Flick, A-Grade student and No. 1 candidate for the student body president. Tracy is confident that her campaign for presidency is going smoothly until Mr McAllister decides to disrupt proceedings and introduce opposition to her as yet unchallenged ride to the top. More than a teenage flick, director Alexander Payne has satirized the popular genre to investigate notions of political and moral corruption. In a clever piece of casting, Matthew Broderick exchanges his Ferris Bueller persona for the devoted and concerned teacher who is slightly burned out from years of teaching. Add to this the disillusionment of a dull marriage and the shameful dismissal of McAllister’s best friend and colleague, and the esteemed civic teacher’s sense of democracy is put to the test. Brilliant performances, subtle humour and an excellent screenplay (an Oscar nomination for Payne and co-writer Jim Taylor). Surprisingly, this film was a box office sleeper. Based on the novel by Tom Perrotta.

results.title: Elder citizen
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Grant McLean and Don Haldane
results.brief_description: Cut off from the life in which they once took an active part, many of Canada’s senior citizens find themselves without companionship or security in their declining years. To show how this problem is being met in one corner of Canada, Fred Davis visits Salt Spring Island near Victoria, British Columbia. Here, we find an organized community for senior citizens that offers a full round of activities with some measure of independence. It has come about largely through the efforts of philanthropic property owner Mrs. Winnie Lautman.

results.title: El Salvador: another Vietnam
results.creator_credit: Catalyst Media Productions, Glenn Silber and Tete Vasconcellos
results.brief_description: Investigates the history of the crises and the forces that have embroiled the United States in this Central American conflict. The film follows the sad history of El Salvador from fifty years of dictatorship, through the civilian-military junta of 1979 and a growing dependency on American aid. Narrated by Mike Farrell.

results.title: El Pueblo
results.brief_description: Depicts life in the small community of Villaleunga del Rosario, set high in the mountains of Andalucia in Spain. The village is sustained by the farms which surround it and a modest workshop manufacturing leather goods. The farms are small, often arid and far from the village itself, providing a meagre living from cattle, sheep and goats. But the sense of community is strong, the people’s enduring allegiance and identity being with the village in which they live.

results.title: El nino
results.creator_credit: RM Associates, LGM, France 3, BBC, Theatre Musical be Paris-Chatelet and Peter Sellars
results.brief_description: A modern opera by John Adams, this is the world premier production of “El nino”, staged at the Theatre Musical be Paris-Chatelet, in 2000. Cast consists of: libretto, John Adams, Peter Sellars; soprano, Dawn Upshaw; mezzo-soprano, Lorraine Hunt Lieberson; baritone, Willard White; theatre of voices, Daniel Bubeck, Brian Cummings and Steven Rickards; performed by the Deutsches Symphonie Orchestre Berlin; conducted by Kent Nagano; dancers, Daniela Graca, Nora Kimball and Michael Shumacher. American minimalist composer John Adams represents the Christmas story, in light of the dawn of a new millennium, by interpreting the story described and prophesied in the New Testament of the Bible, as translated by American Richard Latimore. Adams has fragmented this text, added Old English and utilised the Apocrypha, while focusing on the work of female Latin American poets. Adams’ desire is to depict the birth of Christ simultaneously from several different, largely female, points of view. As the singers and dancers perform the work, a video track, created by Peter Sellars and Yreina D. Cervantez, is displayed as a backdrop, poignantly remarking upon the meagre existence of Hispanic Americans who live in the desert area near Los Angeles, between airport and beach. A stunningly original contemporary work, impressively staged and executed.
